results.title: A Desperate case
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films and Kenneth J. Fairbairn
results.brief_description: A cautionary tale of a typical holiday suitcase. Crammed beyond its capacity, imperfectly fastened, inadequately and confusedly labelled, the railways transport it from station to station, seeking its true abode. Finally, one of its owners comes to the nightmare tribunal where those who maltreat their luggage are dealt with. Did it happen? Was it a dream? Be warned. See this film. Avoid making yours a desperate case.

results.title: A Death in the family
results.creator_credit: James H. Wallace, New Zealand Film Commission, Television New Zealand, Stewart Main and Peter Wells
results.brief_description: An outstanding dramatisation of a group of gay men nursing a friend dying of AIDS in his final 16 days. This beautifully shot film addresses the private realities of living and loving against the public front of a “horror” disease.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James H. Wallace, New Zealand Film Commission, Television New Zealand, Stewart Main and Peter Wells

results.title: A Day with Timmy Page
results.creator_credit: David Hoffman, Iris Hoffman and Amram Nowak Associates
results.brief_description: An 11 year old filmmaker is seen at work with his associates, explaining his techniques and ideas - casting, and other aspects of his filmmaking. Short excerpts from the twenty 10 minute films he has completed in ten months are shown and some very amusing insights into his self-assertive personality and the serious approach he takes are given.

results.title: A Day with a Japanese family
results.creator_credit: Toei and Japan. Ministry of Foreign Affairs
results.brief_description: Depicts the daily life of an average Japanese family; shows their living conditions, problems, and the family relationships. The new Japan is improving living for the vast population and this film emphasises the benefits a family enjoys in the expanding industrial nation.

results.title: A Day on the Grand Canal with the Emperor of China or Surface is illusion but so is depth
results.brief_description: Written and presented by world-renowned British photographer and painter David Hockney, this documentary takes the viewer on a most unusual guided tour of a 72 foot (27 inches top to bottom) ancient late 17th century Chinese scroll created by artist Wang Hui and his seven assistants. The scroll depicts in great depth and detail the Kangxi Emperor’s journey along the Grand Canal in his southern domains providing an intimate and close-up view of Chinese life in the city and back streets. Using a painting by Italian artist Canaletto, and a later Chinese scroll depicting the same journey in a more European style Hockney compares the pieces of work by exploring issues of space, perspective, boundaries and depth. Overall, however, it is Hockney’s analytical appraisal of Wang Hui’s scroll as he interprets the journey section by section theorising on the complexities and relationships between aesthetics, history and spirituality, his awe and admiration of the artist’s skill and precision, and the excellent close-up visuals of the work which provides the viewer with a unique insight into ancient Chinese art and life. Works of art: The Kangxi Emperor’s Southern Inspection Tour (Scroll seven) about 1698 - Wang Hui (1632-1717) and assistants; The Qianlong Emperor’s Southern Inspection Tour (Scroll four) dated 1770 - Xu Yang (active 1750-1776); Capriccio: Plaza San Marco looking South and West 1763 - Giovanni Antonio Canale called Canaletto, Italy 1697-1768

results.title: A Day on the Daly
results.creator_credit: Michael Dillon Film Enterprises and Ausventure Wilderness Association
results.brief_description: Follows a group on a trip down the Daly River, Northern Territory, in boats that were homebuilt from packing cases. Tranquil scenes and beautiful footage. No narration.

results.title: A Day of healing
results.creator_credit: Filmcentre (Melbourne), Associated World Public Relations and Allan Dickes
results.brief_description: Starting with a little of the history of the Austin Hospital, Melbourne, the film quickly moves into the day to day workings of the hospital and many of its special treatment departments - including the kitchen which prepares 2500 meals a day.

results.title: A Day in the night of Jonathan Mole
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, ONF | NFB and Donald Brittain
results.brief_description: A court room parody pointing out the fallacies upon which prejudice thrives and the inadequacy of the laws to eliminate discrimination. Jonathon Mole is a bigoted law clerk who considers himself a victimised average citizen. One night, Jonathan dreams of a ‘perfect’ nation where he is elevated to the status of judge and is presented with a case testing a law which reserves the most desired vocations to person’s of ‘pure’ racial origin. Witnesses for the Prosecution present easily recognizable stereotypes of prejudice and witnesses for the Defence counter with undeniable facts. Although this film was made in 1959 to combat employment discrimination in Canada, the attitudes exposed have repeatedly surfaced throughout the world, since this film’s production.
